PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
National Flag
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they so wish to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear-Free South Pacific
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the World in their efforts to achieve a Nuclear Free South Pacific, and such Decision being endorsed by the people at a General Election.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled Stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the United States Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on Nuclear Vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its Policy to promote the development of Zones of Peace and Nuclear Free Zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Grape Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The financial plight of grape producers, their families and their respective local communities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government act now during the 1985-86 Budget considerations to:
Remove the sales tax impost on all Australian produced wine
Make funds available for the establishment of an institution to administer the restructuring of the grape producing industry.
Place revenue raising imposts on all imported wine and wine spirit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not 'windfall gains' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the present Federal tax system is not equitable, readily understandable or manageable. It is making a material contribution to the decline in ethical standards in Australia, and in the opinion of many eminent Australians it is a tax system that basically makes us into a nation of cheats.

2. Some classes of taxpayers are more heavily taxed than others and two groups, wage and salary earners and small businesses, through the impact of inflation on the progressive rate structure, have suffered disproportionately in recent years.
3. A great many people see cheating the tax system as a necessary response to what they regard as cheating by Governments.

4. Through excessive marginal income tax rates, the spirit of free enterprise and hard work is being stifled. The groups in the community who generate savings are being discouraged from investing those savings in capital for business.

5. Any reform of the taxation system needs to be comprehensive and not piecemeal. Further, it requires an unimpeachable commitment from all political parties and parliamentarians to adopt a totally bi-partisan approach in debating tax reform proposals and legislation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government will use the forthcoming Taxation Summit meeting as the occasion to announce the formation of one or more working parties committed to the development of a taxation system that will ensure that the necessary Government revenue is raised in the most equitable and efficient manner possible and that such working party (parties) be provided with adequate resources so as to permit the tabling of their recommendations in the Parliament not later than 30 June 1986.

Further, your petitioners believe that one of the most significant ways this country could celebrate its Bi-Centenary is through the introduction, by 1988, of legislation that will give the people a fair and equitable taxing system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report as soon as possible: The desirability, feasibility and possible content of a national Bill of Rights for Australia.

I emphasise to honourable senators that this proposed reference is to be undertaken in the spirit of a genuine inquiry with the most fundamental questions concerning a Bill of Rights to be reported on. There are no presumptions or prejudices on the part of honourable senators in regard to this exercise. As I said, the most fundamental and basic questions concerning the Bill of Rights proposal will be open to examination. In fact the whole question of whether some such enterprise should be legislated into our legal framework needs to be addressed; also whether ordinary legislation should be used or whether some form of constitutional entrenchment should be attempted and, if so, whether that should be immediately or after some experience of ordinary legislation in this field.

Indeed, the whole question of the proper relationship between the elected representatives of the people and the non-elected bench of judges needs to be considered because one needs to give serious thought to the problems of handing something to a bench of judges who are ultimately responsible to no-one and who take their positions by patronage. There is a real question of whether we as elected representatives, ultimately answerable every three years in the electorate, should hand over to them the interpretation of broadly phrased provisions in a Bill of Rights. This relationship between the legislature and the judiciary is a very real one that needs to be examined in a very fundamental sense if this enterprise is to be embarked upon.

Clearly, the fact that such a Bill of Rights would have to operate in a Federal system requires a most careful analysis of the appropriate, and not merely the constitutionally possible, exercise of paramount national powers by this Parliament. Merely finding a head of power which could sustain a Bill of Rights would not without more be enough in my view and certainly would not dictate its use. The co-operative use of the plentitude of powers between the Commonwealth and the States would also need to be looked at

I believe the Senate is probably well placed at this stage in this long debate-there has been debate in the public domain for over a decade-to undertake such an inquiry. The Senate has set its own house in order, as it were, by establishing the very effective functioning of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. It is well known that that Committee operates in a way which has been very helpful in the passage of legislation through the Parliament by ensuring, for example, that legislation does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. Indeed, the operation now, and the experience that we have had of the operation, of the Human Rights Commission and the bringing into law and the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act, give us material which we can examine from the point of view of seeing how these forays into the field have fared. I believe the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs will be well placed to undertake this particular project.

I emphasise that it is not the intention of the Committee to devote its attention to any particular model for a Bill of Rights. We do not have in mind any exclusive model as a definitive approach. We say that various possibilities may be put before us and we will consider them all on their merits. The list of rights must not be regarded as closed in any sense. I know from discussions even this morning over breakfast with my good friend Senator Ron Elstob of South Australia that there is the question of whether a Bill of Rights restricted to the traditional well known lists of civil and political rights may be too narrow an approach. As he pointed out, the rights to education, to health care and to work are all matters which we would need to consider if submissions were received on them.

The fact is that there is no hint of subterfuge here. Though it is a most unusual step, I find no difficulty in agreeing with Senator Durack's proposed amendment, although I would like some further time to consider it in conjunction with other senators. I wish to emphasise that, certainly as Chairman of the Caucus Legal and Administrative Committee, I have no knowledge of any particular Bill proposed by the Government in this area and this is not a subterfuge to get the Committee to consider any particular model proposed by the Government.

I emphasise once again that the object of the exercise is to have an open and unprejudiced approach to the whole project and that is the spirit in which it will be undertaken. In conclusion, I believe it is also very important to emphasise that the great merit of public hearings on this proposal will be to enable the community at large to make submissions, to join in the debate and to make an input into the deliberations of this House. I hope that in that spirit the reference will be acceded to by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has no objection to the broad terms of the reference that it is proposed should be put to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by Senator Tate's motion; in other words, that the Committee should give consideration to the concept of a Bill of Rights. No doubt there are various models that can be looked at. Senator Tate has referred to the traditional model and to the views of his colleague Senator Elstob in regard to a very different model from the traditional one. No doubt that sort of matter would be appropriate for the Committee's consideration. There is also, of course, as far as Australia is concerned, the very real question of how such a Bill would fit into the federal system; whether it would be proposed that an amendment be made to the Constitution, whether it would apply only to the Federal powers or whether it should apply to State powers, and so on. So there is a wide range of matters for consideration and certainly a wide range of matters of controversy in relation to a Bill of Rights.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has, as I said, no objection to that matter being considered by the Committee in so far as it is on that plane and in so far as it is a matter for discussion about the broad nature of a Bill of Rights. The Opposition does not have any particular view as to whether in theory there should or should not be a Bill of Rights. It would not be contrary to our stance in relation to this subject for a Senate committee to look at the matter and come forward with various models. However, the Opposition is very firmly opposed to the introduction of a Bill of Rights in Australia by some back-door methods, which is precisely, of course, the way in which this Government has been considering the matter, and particularly the way in which the former Attorney-General, now the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), has been pursuing this subject. Therefore, we are entitled, I think, to be suspicious as to the intentions of the Government in light of what the former Attorney-General said and did-or failed to do-over the course of the last two years. That problem has not been allayed by the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who has talked about drawing up a Bill of Rights which he will presumably be proposing for consideration by this Parliament.

I remind the Senate of the course of events during the year before last when the Government was first elected. One of the centrepieces of its law and justice policy as propounded by Senator Evans at that time was the introduction of a Bill of Rights and use of the external affairs power of the Commonwealth-which has now been so widely interpreted by the High Court in the Tasmanian dam case-to introduce a Bill of Rights which is not an Australian Bill of Rights, or a Bill of Rights which would address current Australian interests and concerns, but a Bill of Rights which would simply give effect to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. That Covenant is expressed in very old and traditional terms and represents the preoccupations of a number of largely Third World member countries of the United Nations which have had very little rights at all, and was supported by countries such as the Soviet Union which has had no civil and political rights at all. Therefore, it was not a satisfactory model. I was interested to hear Senator Tate say that Senator Elstob's views are very different from those propounded by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The other main objection the Opposition had to the proposal was the use of the external affairs power so that this Parliament-

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be worth considering by the Committee, would it not?

—The Committee can consider all options under this reference. The proposal was to use the external affairs power so that this Parliament would be forcing on the States, contrary to ordinary federal principles and structure, that model. It was notorious that legislation along those lines was being drafted. Despite Senator Gareth Evans's adherence to the principles of freedom of information when he was in opposition we could never get him to unveil the Bill of Rights. It was always going to be introduced in a few months time, but it never was introduced. Up to the period of the election last year there had been no Government admission that such a Bill had been drafted and prepared to such an advanced stage. It then emerged that the Bill had reached a very advanced stage and had been considered widely by everybody except members of this Parliament. As I said, I do not know what the state of play is in the Government in relation to the Bill. Certainly the present Attorney-General has expressed very publicly criticism of aspects of it. There are rumours that he is preparing his own Bill. So far this Parliament is no better informed about what the Government's present intentions are than we had been by Senator Evans for the last two years.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter of very grave concern in regard to the future system of government of Australia. If a firm proposal of some sort is ever determined by the Government, it is the duty of the Government to introduce it into Parliament so that we can debate its principles and approach. We are very concerned that the reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs should not be yet another back-door method of making major changes to our Constitution in the form of the Government submitting to the Committee a draft Bill and endeavouring to get the Committee's support and, thereby, bipartisan support, for it ahead of full and public debate in this place and in the community about the divisions and approach of the Government's proposals, if any proposals are finally determined. I am entirely satisfied by what Senator Tate has said in introducing his proposal that that is not his intention or the intention of those who support this reference. As I said, the Opposition members of the Committee will certainly not be seeking to use this reference for that purpose at all. On the face of it, there would never have been any objection whatsoever by the Opposition to this motion going through at this stage in its present terms, even without debate. I imagine that there would be very great debate ultimately on any report the Committee brought in on such a controversial subject. However, in view of what has gone on in the last two years, the Opposition is very concerned to ensure that any proposals by the Government are not simply put to the Committee so as to test them out before the Committee ahead of their being introduced into this Parliament as a Bill and of proper consideration being given to them before the Committee would look at them. In order to ensure that, I move the following amendment:

At end of motion add: ', but that the Committee, in the course of its inquiry, not consider the provisions of any Bill on this subject prepared by the Government unless such Bill has been introduced into the Senate and referred to the Committee by a further resolution'.

In other words, I envisage that the Government would introduce its measure into this place. We would have a full second reading debate on it. If the Committee were still considering various other options no doubt the Senate would determine whether this Government's proposal should be considered by the Committee. As I have said, the Government may never introduce such legislation. It may wait until the Committee reports. I do not know what the Government will do. We have never been able to find out what the Government intends to do and that is what is concerning us. For two years the Government has been keeping secret what its proposals are despite the noises that it makes about its support for a Bill of Rights. We want to ensure that if the Government ever comes to any firm decision on this matter it will make its position known publicly so that it can be debated in this chamber and not in the deliberations of the Committee. The latter would be a totally unsatisfactory approach to a matter of this kind.

As I have said, the Opposition is quite happy for the Committee to look at the subject of a Bill of Rights in very general terms but it demands that if the Government has its own proposal prepared and determined it should introduce it here first, and not to the Committee without giving the Senate or the Parliament an opportunity to debate it and determine whether it is a model which it will entertain or reject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will support the motion. I am also attracted to the amendment. Senator Tate has outlined the reasons for the proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. He has outlined some of the matters that ought to be considered by the Committee. The very definition of what a right is could be another matter for consideration by the Committee. Questions are often raised as to whether or not there is any such thing as an inherent, absolute right; and why rights are asserted when interests are threatened in some way by the conflicting interests of others. Should rights be looked at as particular applications of some greater and higher principle and, if so, what are those principles? I wish the Committee every success in its consideration of those very important and fundamental issues. I expect that the report will come down in about 1990.
—Maybe in time for the tricentennial.

—Maybe. These are very serious matters and I think it is about time that they were logically addressed and in a bipartisan manner. I do, however, warn the members of the Committee, although they do not need warning because they are all experienced people, that it will be a quite difficult and time consuming task. The Committee is very brave to take on this reference. I believe it is a very important reference and I congratulate Senator Tate for bringing it before the Committee and those Committee members who have devised the reference motion for consideration by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak very briefly on this matter. I do not imagine that we will determine the question and vote on it today. I appreciate what Senator Harradine has said. This certainly is a difficult question which is fraught with problems in that it is highly political. Therefore, the suggestion has been made that a general discussion be held which would take into account the various possibilities that are available for the consideration of the issue of human rights in this country. It may not result in the introduction of a Bill of Rights at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak particularly because this debate has already led to some misconceptions on the part of the local Press, which I think sees the proposal as a manoeuvre connected with the internal problems of the Australian Labor Party. That is not the intention of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in taking on this reference. I will read into the record a statement which I have made, as Chairman of the Attorney-General's Committee of the Opposition parties' and which I released this morning. I said:

I refer to an article by one Louise Dodson appearing in the Financial Review of the 18th April 1985. The article refers to certain internecine fighting between the Federal Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen and certain members of the Caucus' Legal and Administration Committee. It concludes that the Attorney-General had suffered a set back from the Caucus committee's commitment ''to the introduction of a bill of rights which will now be referred to a bipartisan Senate Committee.''

This is apparently intended to refer to a decision by the all Party Constitutional and Legal Committee of the Senate which now proposes to investigate ''the desirability, feasibility and possible content of a Bill of Rights for Australia.''

As a member of that Committee I can assure the public that the Committee is prepared to discuss the general subject of a possible Bill of Rights but it is totally untrue to suggest that any form of such a Bill, whether proposed by Senator Evans, the previous Attorney or the present Attorney-General is the subject of such an inquiry. Any such proposal would be a separate matter for consideration by the Senate.

As is well known, the Evans Bill of Rights was kept from the public prior to the 1984 election and has never been presented to this Parliament in any form. There is no proposal at present that the Senate Committee consider the terms of such a bill and the Liberal Senators have no intention of intervening in the squabble between the Labor factions over such a Bill.
The inquiry will operate under a general charter that will enable the Committee to examine the whole subject of enforcement of human rights in this country.

That statement supports the position which Senator Durack stated on behalf of the Opposition that, if a specific Bill is to be referred to, it should be referred to by this Senate. I think that is the position taken by members of the Committee who sit on this side of the chamber. As far as this whole question is concerned, I have no doubt that specific Bills will be looked at and that types and forms of a Bill of Rights will be considered. The shadow Attorney-General, Senator Durack, is right in saying that one should not see this inquiry as a means of referring, by a back-door method, a Bill which as yet has not actually been brought forward. I suppose that will be only one of the matters which will be considered by the Committee.

I have made those remarks because I think there is some misconception on the part of the Press as to the purpose of the proposed inquiry. I am sure the Opposition members are not concerned in playing a part in any way in the discussions among the factions of the Labor Party, which are already quite adequate in number without any help from us. This proposed inquiry could do a lot of good because the whole question of human rights in this country has to be taken from the plane it has descended to and looked at by a committee of the Senate. I hope, therefore, that the motion and Senator Durack's amendment, in such form as it will subsequently be determined, will be passed so that we can get on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I contribute briefly to the debate since my own contribution to the development of human rights legislation in this country seems to be somewhat in the eye of the storm at the moment. I approach this debate with some diffidence but want to make a couple of brief points. The first is that I can understand the concern that beats in the breasts of the Opposition that it is not appropriate that a Senate Committee approach the task of analysing a particular piece of legislation without that piece of legislation or proposed legislation being squarely before it in its terms of reference. To that extent I would not object to the general thrust of the proposed amendment to the reference going to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I rise, however, to enter one caveat, and it is this: I would think it unfortunate if the terms of this amendment were construed by the Committee as precluding it from looking at the terms of particular models that have emerged, officially and unofficially, in the past for translating Bill of Rights aspirations into legislative reality. If I have learned anything from my participation in this debate on and off over the last 14 years or so, it is that the most enormous difficulty one has in getting sensible debate on the Bill of Rights issue is getting people to focus on the actual issues of detail involved, and to stop simply swapping high level and high-blown rhetoric about the general principles involved. The whole art of translating the kind of aspirations contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, for example, into domestic Bill of Rights legislation is to get the drafting language right and to create rights that are capable of enforcement in a practical way by the courts or by whatever other institution is created or modified for the purpose of giving those rights reality on the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: It is most important for the Committee to be able not just to focus on questions of general principle and the desirability or undesirability of Bills of Rights in the abstract; it should be possible for the Committee to address itself squarely to the kinds of practical difficulties involved in the drafting in legislative language of particular rights as well as simply identifying in general terms what rights might be appropriate for treatment in this way. Equally, it is also important for the Committee to be able to focus by reference to particular models that have emerged in the past, like the 1973 Murphy Bill or like other drafts that have been prepared around the place from time to time. One was introduced in New Zealand recently. That is another useful example. But equally there have been other drafting exercises conducted within government, including my own last year, which have addressed these problems and sought to resolve them.

I make the point as forcefully as I can that, though I do not think the Committee should regard its task as being to report on any particular piece of putative legislation to recommend its adoption or otherwise, it should be able to have before it any model that has been prepared in any context whatever so that it can come to grips in a systematic and intelligent way with the problems of drafting a Bill of Rights, getting the substantive rights properly identified and getting procedures for their recognition, declaration and enforcement which are workable and not counter-productive. To come to grips with those sorts of issues demands willingness on the part of the Committee to come to grips not only with matters of generality but matters of detail. That will demand some attention to a variety of models that have been prepared. With those caveats, I support the proposal and the amendment which has been moved to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that my party, the Australian Democrats, and I have no particular objections to Senator Durack's amendment and we will be supporting it. On the other hand, I must say that I am not quite sure that it will achieve much, other than to ensure that an official government proposal does not go to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs until it has been introduced into the Senate. Since the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is a member of the House of Representatives, I assume that means it will go into the House of Representatives and be passed there first; unless, of course, Mr Hawke does another one of his amazing Cabinet shuffles and we get back the old Attorney-General.
—That would be amazing.
—We will not pursue that.

—Why don't you move to correct 'Senate' to 'Parliament' to make it clear that procedural things of that kind ought not to be a barrier? There is no issue of principle involved there, is there, Senator Durack?

—I do not know. I am not planning to mess about with the motion before us today. It is just that I want to address some queries that I have about this. It certainly will not stop other political parties from putting forward a draft Bill to the Committee. It is not going to prevent any independent senator or member-I would suggest, with respect, that that includes the Attorney-General, the shadow Attorney-General, or some other member-from dreaming up a draft and shuffling that off to the Committee as an independent Bill. I presume that it does not include-Senator Gareth Evans has already alluded to this-the 1973 Murphy proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen spoke earlier about back-door methods. I do not know if I can dream up more back-door methods than he can, but I would suggest that it is also possible for the Government to draft a Bill and send it off to one of the multitude of constitutional experts who seem to abound in the community, or to some political scientist, to append to a submission that will go to the Committee anyway. I presume that if the Attorney-General's Department is making a submission to the Committee, and that is not unheard of, it could address all the principles and proposals of the official Government line, without actually putting those principles and proposals into formal draft Bill form.

As I said, we have no objections to Senator Durack's amendment. I think he is probably right in saying that the Government is in a different position from everybody else and, therefore, any official Government position ought to be treated somewhat differently from other submissions and drafts. I guess this motion does prevent the Government from sending off one or more draft Bills just to stir the waters to see what comes to the top. To that extent, I think it is reasonable enough, but it is also a relatively harmless amendment that will not stop the Committee addressing itself to the real issues, as wide as they are, of human rights legislation and what should and should not be incorporated in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Tate on his initiative in moving to have this matter referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Many Australians feel that it is time for Australia to have a Bill of Rights. I have always felt that we should follow other Bills of Rights, such as the American Bill of Rights. I also believe that an Australian Bill of Rights should give people the right to medical services, the right to education and the right to work. I will make a submission to the Committee along those lines. That does not mean that all the other rights, the democratic rights that we hold very dear, are not important.

SPEECH.PARA: It is time for Australia to look at the whole aspect of rights for its people. Perhaps this can be done through a committee, which adopts a bipartisan approach. The committees of this Senate have been successful in many areas. That may be a way of bringing together the public and the politicians of this country to put up sensible solutions and get some agreement on them. Perhaps this is the way to proceed. I think that this is an important issue. Once again, I congratulate Senator Tate for initiating this move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs I welcome the reference and the challenge it presents. We saw the question debated last year in what I think can be described as somewhat emotive circumstances, which were not helped, I believe, by the then secret Bill of the former Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the selective leaking of that Bill towards the end of last year. As the Senate is aware, a great volume of material was floating around but it was not being accumulated in any central way. It was not being analysed correctly and properly in a way that a Senate committee can treat such material. Therefore, I believe that the best forum within this Parliament to debate in a sane, rational and unemotive way a question that is of major significance and major importance is a committee of the Senate such as this Committee. On that basis, senators on my side of the Senate welcome the reference.

SPEECH.PARA: I support Senator Durack's amendment. It is a pity, I suppose, that it is necessary as one would think that the proper course of action would be for the Government first to introduce a Bill if it has a Bill in mind and, if it wishes to seek reference of the Bill to a committee, to do so. One might say we should not be suspicious on this side of the chamber. However, having read articles such as that which appeared in the Australian Financial Review yesterday, which alleged sniping between the former Attorney-General and the current Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) as to who had the better prospective Bill, and having heard the suggestion by some that the Government will attempt to use this Committee to legitimise one or other of those prospective Bills, I think that unfortunately an amendment of this kind is necessary to remind the Government of what we believe to be the correct course of action.

Senator Haines has said that the amendment is not foolproof. Very few motions, parts of motions or pieces of legislation that pass through the Parliament are foolproof. However, the sentiment of the amendment is absolutely clear. It is clear to those of us on the Committee, as I am sure it is clear to senators at large. What the amendment is saying, in effect, is that if the Government is of a mind to introduce a Bill it should not take the back door road, it should not attempt to take a short cut and seek a legitimisation by the Committee outside of the Parliament; it should be open and frank, put down its Bill in the Parliament and then do what it wishes to do with it. As I said, I support the reference. I look forward to the challenge it will provide. I support the amendment to ensure that the Government is reminded of its proper responsibility in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Western Australia)-by leave-As a result of discussion around the chamber in relation to the amendment-it is obvious that the principle of the amendment has been supported-it has been suggested that it would be more appropriate if the amendment, instead of referring to a Bill introduced into the Senate, referred to a Bill introduced into the Parliament. I think there has been general agreement about that. I would be happy to seek to amend my proposed amendment by substituting the word 'Parliament' for the word 'Senate'.
—Is leave granted to amend the amendment?

—I am advised that there may be some technical difficulty. Perhaps Senator Haines has already foreshadowed it. I suggest we should adjourn the matter until later in the day so that it can be considered.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1985DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing today the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1985 and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1985. Yesterday I was saying that the taxation system in this country is viewed by many people in the community as being very unfair. It is unfair when we see so many instances where people virtually can pay or not pay. In other words, they treat tax as optional, whereas the majority of wage earners are forced to pay their tax through pay-as-you-earn taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: If the laws are not recognised by the people as being fair and are not seen to be fair, there will be a tendency for people further to dodge their responsibilities. No country such as ours can afford to let that happen. I remind the Senate that this country is very large and our responsibilities for roads, communications and transport are immense. To build roads in this country and to provide services such as telephones, electricity and water are immense undertakings. We all like our quarter acre block of land and our cities are expanding. Taxation in this country will never be low because of the desires we have. It is only fair that people who live in isolated areas should get the same services as city people. Years ago there was a lot of danger because people in isolated areas had no communications-no telephones, radio or any other facilities. Today we are looking at the possibility of satellites bringing television and other necessities to people living in isolated areas. If we are to be a great nation and a nation that thinks something of its population, this is the way we must go. But all this costs money.

While we allow our wealthy people not to pay their taxation, which provides the right services for our population, our task is almost impossible. Because of the lack of government direction in the past-by the Fraser Government from 1975 to the time when it was put out of office-this situation developed to such an extent that we estimate that $7 billion was lost to taxation. This means something like $30 a week in round figures for the average wage and salary earner. The level of taxation in this country is too high. This Government is trying to reduce that level.

Yesterday Senator Watson said that it is bad for the economy to try to recover taxes. Senator Haines said that it was very unfair to use retrospective legislation. Is it unfair that laws should be seen to be just and equitable? I believe that the only way to stop taxation dodging, evasion and avoidance is to have retrospective legislation in this area. Go and ask the wage and salary earners-

TALK.START.PARA: —What about other things you don't like?

—Senator Haines had her say yesterday. Ask the wage and salary earners whether they believe the wealthy and the privileged of this country should not pay their share. No one can substantiate an argument that wage and salary earners should foot the bill for these people.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said when I was speaking in this debate yesterday, if this situation is allowed to continue, other people will be encouraged to do the same. If one is having a drink at a club and mixing with people who have been dodging or avoiding the payment of tax one is asked: 'What is wrong with you-are you a fool? Why don't you dodge tax?' Consequently people are encouraged to follow the leader and evade paying taxation by this sort of peer group attitude.

We understand that taxation has to be paid if we are to enjoy the fruits of our labour. We have to pay taxation so that this country can be defended and feel secure. No one is going to complain about that. Australians have the right to live the way they want to. I would prefer that we did not spend large sums on defence. However, the reality of the situation is that most certainly people will try to take away from us what we have if we do not defend ourselves. That reality has been proven many times over. It is right and just that we provide a reasonable level of social security for our people. Australians who are ill or out of work are paid a sum. This type of arrangement does not exist in all countries. If we do not provide these services there would be a tendency for other ideologies that are foreign and unacceptable to us to be adopted in this country. There are all sorts of reasons why there is a need for a decent standard of living and some assurance that we will be protected. However, to do that we have to have a reasonable tax return. People have to be shown that it is in their interests to pay taxation.

Yesterday Senator Haines cited the example of Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd paying tax of 1.11c in the dollar. She also mentioned the amount of tax paid by some other companies. This sort of thing is a disgrace. Companies are deliberately employing virtually hundreds of tax consultants, lawyers or accountants to do nothing else but look for loopholes in the law so that the payment of tax can be avoided and evaded. How many wage and salary earners can afford to employ tax consultants, lawyers or accountants to look for these things? Is it morally right that this sort of thing should happen? In my opinion, it is unforgivable.

If we cannot close off these loopholes with legislation, perhaps we should be setting down guidelines about people's responsibility to pay tax and saying to the Commissioner of Taxation: 'You will apply these'. In that case, we would have to give more discretionary power to the Commissioner. Many politicians with whom I have spoken say: 'That is not right'. As I have always said, either we should give more discretionary powers to the Commissioner or we should use the retrospective taxation laws to recover unpaid tax where people have tried to avoid or evade taxation. It is only legal loopholes that they are exploiting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get the laws right in the first place?

—It is probably impossible for parliaments anywhere in the world to legislate to close all loopholes in taxation laws. I honestly believe that. We, the law-makers of this land, should be looking at either using retrospective laws in regard to this matter or giving the Commissioner of Taxation more discretionary powers. The laws must be fair. If they are not fair, we encourage all sections of the community to break them, and that is unpalatable.
—Who determines whether it is fair?

—The Parliament. We are elected as representatives of people of this nation, and it must be within our power to determine that. The tax laws are so important. In regard to general law, people say that Australia's laws are fair, and they are seen to be fair; but our taxation laws are not fair-and that is the great difference. It is about time we changed that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his policy speech last year, promised the public that, once re-elected, the Government would re-introduce the twice rejected bottom of the harbour legislation, which would recoup only a few hundred million dollars from those who have sought to escape their taxation responsibilities. It is probably impossible to recoup the $7 billion which some people have avoided paying. This measure will bring back only a few hundred million dollars, but it is important as a warning to those who would, in the future, attempt to avoid and evade taxation responsibilities. Parliament should bring in these laws and penalties. They are only very small penalties; they do not involve the full loss that has occurred over 12 years or more. It is important for the Parliament to show that it is prepared to recover this money. This would serve as a warning to others who may attempt to avoid their responsibilities. That is the important point.

If we are to have a united nation, which should be the principle behind every politician, no matter the particular party, that is important. But we are not doing that in this regard. The people who get up early in the morning, travel to work, take off their coats and do a job know that they are discriminated against. When one talks to them one hears the attitude: 'Why should I do this when I am paying the majority? Why can't the business people?'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a fault of the existing tax laws, which should be remedied. Why does the Government not concentrate on that?

—Why does Senator Hill continually oppose this? He will be speaking after my speech. Senator Hill will say what a terrible thing it is to recover this money. That is why those opposite were put out of office. When the Liberal Government appointed Frank Costigan to look at the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, it did not do so with the idea of overcoming all the difficulties and the rottenness in that union, of which I am ashamed, as an ex-trade unionist. Business people in high places were using the crooked people in that union to assist them in their illegal operations. That is a disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of working people, small business people and everyone who contributes to this great nation were disgusted with what was happening. That is why the majority of business people are coming to Labor. They have deserted their traditional Party, the Liberal Party. One can see this. I see it in my office in Adelaide and many other politicians are seeing it, simply because the Opposition, as a political party, would not take the hard option. Those opposite are virtually saying to some of their friends in high places: 'We will let you avoid and evade taxation laws, but the working people, who really make this country, will pay'. That is a thorough disgrace.

We do not have the numbers in the Senate to bring this legislation into effect. This legislation would be fair, and would show the people of this nation that we are attempting to stop the rogues, the thieves and the vagabonds from not paying their tax. They will continue to get away with it, but the people of this nation will not forget it. The Opposition is being un-Australian in its attitude, by its opposition-

TALK.START.PARA: —Un-Australian by not having retrospective penal legislation?

—Yes, the Opposition is being un-Australian because for years everyone who has paid tax has been paying $30 a week too much. That is an outrage. The Opposition has given no warning to the tax dodgers. It has encouraged them to go on year after year in their avoidance and evasion. It has said to the people who really do the work in this country: 'You will pay'. Because of this the Opposition will never get back into power.
—You cannot exercise retrospective penalties in the way you want to.

—We need retrospective laws. How much can average working people take? They do not have the power or the money to employ people to look into taxation dodging. There is no doubt about it. The laws are meaningful but skilled lawyers and accountants find small holes in those laws so that the dodgers can be allowed not to pay their taxation. Do not tell me that that is fair or reasonable. The Opposition should ask the people outside if it thinks it is. That will not work. We all pay our taxation. There is no way we can get out of it. We are on a salary. There is very little anyone on a wage or salary can do, but those who can form another business are allowed to transfer money to that business, write that business off, sink it, collect the money and not pay taxation.
—If you see that as a distortion, that is what you should be seeking to overcome.

—The honourable member will say that he opposes the legislation. He will never get back into government with that attitude. It is our duty to try to recover the money. It is important not only to get that money, but also to show the people that we are not prepared to allow the dodgers and the despicable people who do not pay their share to get away with it. That is what the Opposition is allowing them to do, and I think it is a disgrace. One can never condone it; it is totally unfair. It is just unbelievable that the Opposition persists in doing that and trying to make the taxation system in this country so unfair. That is the thing that will keep the Opposition out of office.

SPEECH.PARA: We will continually bring in these Bills until we get the numbers in this place. People will see that unless we get the numbers we cannot implement the legislation that will make this society fair and equitable. That is what it is about. It comes back to numbers. One can have the best argument in the world, but unless one has the numbers it means nothing. That is what we are showing to the people outside and will show them continuously until they understand it. It is costing them a lot of money by not allowing us to have the numbers in the Senate so that we can bring fairness and equity into society. That situation has to come about. No government can survive unless that happens. I plead with honourable senators to reconsider their attitude to this proposition. I think that Australians should look to a better and a fairer society. Unless the Opposition indicates support for this, less and less trust will be placed in politicians by the general population.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again oppose the Government's attempts to introduce retrospective taxation laws into this country. I think it is the fifth time that we have debated attempts by the Government to tax Australians retrospectively. I might say, before I get to the substance of my contribution, that the goal that has just been put by Senator Elstob of fairness and justice within the taxation system is something in which we all obviously concur. Where we part is on whether retrospective taxation is a legitimate tool to achieve that goal. It seems to us on this side of the chamber that it is hard to imagine any act that is more unfair or unjust than to introduce taxation laws that impose a new taxation burden and backdate them. I am disappointed that that cannot be seen by Senator Elstob, because I accept the motive of his contribution. The view that he has put is that, if we impose retrospectivity in some cases, it will indicate to the Australian public that we want to achieve a system that is fair and just. But who makes the judgment in that instance? Where does it start and where does it end? Once one opens the door to retrospectivity as a legitimate means of taxation where does it end?

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the question can be asked: Why are we debating these Bills again and again? Why are we debating them for the fifth time when the Government knows that they will not pass the Senate, that the Senate does not hold the Government's views in relation to retrospective tax? The short answer is that the Bills were brought on suddenly yesterday because of the Government's failure to maintain a sensible legislative program. The Government simply ran out of business. That is not surprising when one looks at the fact that its economic program is in chaos. One wakes up each day and finds that the Australian dollar has collapsed yet again. Yesterday we were looking at 63c against the American dollar. This morning we found that overnight there had been a further slip of 2c. In only a few months the Australian dollar has fallen against that currency by about 20 per cent. We heard on the radio this morning that it now costs two Australian dollars to buy one pound sterling whereas a few months ago it was $A1.40 to buy a pound sterling.

I submit that it is terrifying that the international assessment of the value of the Australian economy should be crashing in this way. It will be terrifying for every ordinary Australian, the type of person to whom Senator Elstob was referring. Such a person, who has perhaps saved for years for an overseas trip, will be terrified when later this year he finds how much more that trip will cost him. This situation will affect small business which, when it looks to purchase some overseas equipment, will find that in a few months the price has gone up by 20 per cent. It is terrifying when, under this Government's short-sighted wages policy, the cost of consumer items flows through to wages, costs and then inflation. The modest gains we have seen in the recovery to date will be wiped out by this Government's short-sighted and incorrect economic policies.

It is not surprising that the Government has other things on its mind than the orderly conduct of its legislative program. But apart from its disorganisation, which we are witnessing, it is clear that we will debate these Bills again in any event in due course. In the longer term one has to ask why. The answer would appear to be two-fold. We heard it yesterday, particularly from Senator Richardson and Senator Elstob. Fortunately, Senator Elstob's contribution today was on a different plane. The reason is that these Bills provide a vehicle for the Australian Labor Party, the Labor Government, to continue the myth that the former Government, the Fraser Government, was associated with tax cheats and failed to address the tax avoidance industry. That might seem to the Labor Party to be good politics, especially when it is on the ropes, as appears to be the case at the moment, but it simply does not stand objective analysis.

Artificial or contrived taxation avoidance schemes started as far back as the mid-1970s. I remind the Senate that the now Treasurer, Mr Keating, in fact acknowledged that. I refer to a broadcast of the 4BC talkback program on 10 September 1982 in which he said:
When we were in Government between '73 and '75 the tax avoidance industry started to move into sophisticated contrived schemes. Schemes that were artificial devices to avoid tax.

As was acknowledged by Treasurer Keating, this situation started to develop in the mid-1970s. The Fraser Government signalled the start of its fight against tax avoidance in a major way as far back as 1977 when the the Treasurer, the late Sir Phillip Lynch, as is recorded in Hansard, said:

The Government is well aware of the activities of tax planners who, increasingly, are promoting tax avoidance schemes and arrangements throughout the business and professional community. We propose to crack down hard on such practices.

That was what Treasurer Lynch said in 1977 and that was exactly what happened: The Government went on a major attack which continued during its term in office. I know figures can be a little tiresome, but I think they are worth repeating. I remind the Senate that in 1977 the former Government introduced 20 taxation Acts totalling 83 pages. Fourteen of those pages were related to taxation avoidance. In the following year there were a further 45 Acts totalling 308 pages, of which 149 pages were tax avoidance related legislation. In 1979, 26 Acts were introduced totalling 98 pages, of which 45 pages were related to taxation avoidance. In 1980 a further 21 Acts, including 96 pages of taxation avoidance legislation, were introduced. A total of 304 pages of the statutes were devoted to methods being adopted by the former Government to fight taxation avoidance.

That is not acknowledged by the Government in office today. That was not acknowledged in the speeches that were made yesterday. What has further not been acknowledged is that the former Government was successful in its challenge to combat artificial and contrived taxation avoidance schemes. No lesser authority than the Taxation Commissioner reached that conclusion. I will read from a letter which was sent to the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, shortly before he left that position and which he incorporated in Hansard on 30 March 1984. The Taxation Commissioner said:

The evidence available to this office suggests that the introduction on 27 May 1981 of part IVA (of the Taxation Act) with effect from that date effectively put a stop to the promotion of new tax avoidance schemes of a blatant, artificial or contrived nature.

In other words, the Taxation Commissioner said that the action of the former Government was successful in stamping out these schemes. I respectfully adopt the words of Mr Howard in the debate I mentioned, when he said:
There could be no more telling judgment on the quality and effectiveness of the action taken by the last Government on that issue than that judgment by the Commissioner of Taxation.

As I have said, although honourable senators would not have believed it from yesterday's debate, the Liberal Government was successful in bringing to an end taxation avoidance measures of that nature. The Labor Government, unfortunately, continues to misrepresent that position to the Australian people, to mislead the Australian people in that way. It should accept the truth and the reality; that is, that no other government in Australia's history was so active in the fight against tax evasion.

The other misrepresentation which the Government tends to use on these occasions and which seems to be part of the reason why it continually introduces Bills such as this to facilitate such debates is its generalisation of tax evasion under the emotive phrase 'bottom of the harbour', which, of course, conjures up visions of a fraudulent and particularly undesirable form of evasion, with companies simply being wiped out, shredded and dropped to the bottom of the harbour. As the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) said, I think aptly, when these Bills were being debated in the other place, it is becoming the new McCarthyist smear. We hear it time and again. These debates are used by the Government to lump the whole tax avoidance area within this particularly emotive and undesirable phrasing. Bottom of the harbour schemes in fact were responsible for a relatively small proportion of tax avoided during the 1970s, and the principals of such schemes are in the criminal courts where they should be. In no way has their conduct been condoned by the previous Government. Quite to the contrary, that Government condemned it. I need not again go through the whole history of the action that the former Government took to stamp it out.

Furthermore, what is not said by the Labor Government is that not only did the Liberal and National parties in coalition knock out such schemes, but also the tax avoided during the period when the industry was in its so-called flourishing state is steadily being recovered. I remind the Senate that the Special Prosecutor, Roger Gyles, QC, who was appointed by the Fraser Government-that is worth repeating; he was appointed by the Fraser Government-in 1982, as at the last Budget had netted $330m and was seeking a further $257m. Now that the Commissioner of Taxation is raising assessments in relation to company stripping operations under section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act we can expect a lot more to be forthcoming. What has happened is that the schemes were knocked out by the former Government's action and, furthermore, tax that was avoided during the 1970s is being steadily recovered.

The other reason for the legislation we are debating, apart from its being an attempt to win cheap political points through misrepresentation, is, it would appear, that it is a desperate lunge by the Government for further tax revenue. I guess that that is not surprising, because its Budget has blown out to a shortfall of perhaps some $10 billion. What a boast! We have the highest deficit in Australia's peacetime history from the highest taxing government in Australia's peacetime history and-I suppose it follows logically and it certainly is not surprising-the highest spending government in Australia's history. What a claim to fame by which this Government will be remembered.

We will not endorse retrospective taxation as a means of raising further revenue for this Government. One of the cardinal certainties of our democratic system if it is to remain stable and strong-we heard Senator Elstob talk about the importance of unity, a point with which we agree-is for a government not to tax retrospectively. I know that this Government says that it will impose the tax retrospectively only in the event of artificial or contrived taxation schemes. But as I said earlier, who decides the ground rules? Who decides when schemes are artificially contrived? Of course, surprise, surprise, it is the Government. Thus we see legislation of this nature before us. Where does retrospectivity start and where does it end?

I am pleased that I can say in this chamber that I have opposed retrospective taxation on every occasion such legislation has been introduced during my time here, including the one occasion when retrospective taxation legislation was introduced by my own side. This is more than any member of the Australian Labor Party can claim because we know, of course, if that were their view and they were prepared to stand on their principles they would be expelled from the Party. However, that is another debate. I remember calling for the previous Government, my Government, to exhaust existing remedies. That is what I do again today to this Government. I said that by way of interjection to Senator Elstob.

It was pleasing last year to hear Special Prosecutor Gyles, to whom I have referred, say that he could not understand why, for example, section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was not being used to hit at artificial schemes. This is a better way to go than to introduce retrospective taxation laws. This shows that we can achieve the same goal-the goal Senator Elstob was seeking to achieve-by the better means of properly enforcing the existing legislation. I remember that Special Prosecutor Gyles said in reply to a question I asked him at a Sydney meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that he could not understand why the charge of conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth had not more readily been utilised in relation to these more dramatic and obviously criminal attempts to evade taxation.

I repeat that if we utilise the existing provisions in the Act we will achieve the same object by a much more satisfactory means. That is what I said when we were in government. That is what I say to this Government. Legislation of this nature is unnecessary and undesirable even to achieve the objectives that Senator Elstob is after. It is simply an unnecessary and undesirable short-cut because it imposes legislation which places in jeopardy the principle of certainty under the law, a principle which I would think Senator Elstob would certainly consider important.

Of course, this is the action of a government desperate for more money. I suppose that governments desperate for money tend to sacrifice principle. Of course, that is what we are seeing in relation to the proposed taxation summit- otherwise now commonly referred to as the taxation farce. This is a desperate lunge by the Government for further revenue. The taxation summit will be all about how to impose new taxes and raise more revenue. The tragedy of that of course is that respected academics and respected institutions are being snared within the farce in the misguided belief that they will contribute to taxation reform.

As I think was said wisely yesterday by Senator Peter Rae in the debate on the Bills, the Australian Labor Party has split into its factions and each of the factions is taking a position of advocating the raising of greater revenue. The Left wants to raise more revenue through the summit by imposing capital, wealth and death duties. The Centre Left wants to do this by capital transfer taxes and wealth and expenditure taxes. Labor Unity proposes to do this by new capital taxes and new consumption taxes. The New South Wales Right seems to be taking a somewhat similar position by wanting to impose the same new additional taxes. However, what they have all agreed on is that we should have retrospective taxation laws. I can say that I certainly have not heard-although some other senators might-any suggestion that the question of retrospectivity should be put to the taxation summit as either a desirable or an undesirable principle. That is something the Labor Party regards as beyond debate.

The only remaining major area of taxation avoidance which the Government should be tackling is the cash economy. One reads of estimates that it is costing the economy between 10 and 15 per cent of gross domestic product. This would be between $5 billion and $8 billion annually. That is the area this Government should be concentrating on. The Fraser Government was tackling this last major area of taxation avoidance. I remind the Senate that the prescribed payments system which the Fraser Government introduced netted some 60,000 new taxpayers. The reforms that the coalition put to the Australian people at the last election included this firm commitment:
To reduce the present heavy reliance on personal tax as a source of revenue by broadening the tax base and putting greater reliance in indirect taxation.

That would have been a further step in the direction of countering the cash of a black economy. To provide a better balance between direct and indirect taxation in our system would strike a blow at avoidance through the cash economy. Of course, the Hawke Government in fact failed at the last election to put any tax policy to the Australian people. The policy of the Liberal Party was to give tax relief. As I said, Labor's non-policy will be to raise revenue through new taxes and in an effort to supplement income from its attempt to impose retrospective tax on the Australian people, as it is seeking to do today. That is an attempt which we on this side of the chamber will oppose again and again each time the Government attempts to introduce legislation of that type into this place.

In summary what I say to the Labor Government is that retrospective tax laws are unnecessary and undesirable. The Government should concentrate on getting its prospective tax laws right and on enforcing existing laws. The Government should accept what the Commissioner of Taxation said about the Fraser Government's program of combating tax avoidance and should cease attempting to win cheap political points through misrepresentation. The Labor Government ought to look to the expenditure side of its Budget rather than attempting to raise revenue at the cost of the loss of certainty under the law. The Labor Government should acknowledge that the Opposition will support legislation to clamp down on the vestiges of any past avoidance practices that still remain and on any new practices, as it recently did under the trust recoupment Bills. The Government ought to be providing answers to the last major area of taxation avoidance-the cash economy. If the Labor Government concentrated on these matters I suggest it would be rendering a more worthwhile service to the Australian people for what remains of its term of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an acute sense of deja vu, as other speakers in this debate have had, as I restate what substantially are old arguments and what appear to be intractable and diverse points of view on this matter of taxation retrospectivity. As I see it, the main problem is the need to distinguish in one's mind between two principles-tax equity and so-called retrospectivity. I will deal with the question of retrospectivity a little later because I think there are points in that regard which have not yet arisen in this debate and which I would like to draw to the attention of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of tax equity is one which certainly has determined my view. As in the past, I will vote with the Government on this legislation. That will, as everybody knows, represent a division of opinion within the Australian Democrats. I make no apologies for that. I think it is part of the logic of the Australian Democrats, and has been since our foundation, that we operate as members of parliament. We do not always or necessarily operate along caucusing lines. In fact, operating along caucusing lines basically is anathema to us. If we can achieve consensus on our point of view, so much the better. That is a good and healthy thing and it is possibly something of a microcosm as to what could be a more enlightened future government of this country than one based on sheer confrontation which is in itself so wasteful.

There are, as I say, two very respectable principles at stake and the choice between them is a difficult one. The community finds it a difficult one, just as the Australian Democrats find it a difficult one. I would like to address my remarks to both points-tax equity and retrospectivity-because they seem to be the nub of this debate. I can only agree with what Senator Elstob said. One can, I think, properly take an old-fashioned view of the general obligation of citizens to contribute to society and to the protection and facilities that government and society give them. I think that is fundamental. It is something which, as I said, is old-fashioned. We would no longer laugh at the concept of Sir Walter Scott, who, so that he could pay all of his debts rather than remain a bankrupt, wrote novel after novel until he killed himself. One can see a morality in that view and a basic soundness of mind and attitude which is perhaps something which we in our modern societies have lost and which we have lost to our discredit and-probably also, I suggest-to our disadvantage.

That does not mean that we have to go further and further along the same path. I suggest that it ought to be the first and foremost obligation of those who can best afford to pay to contribute towards the costs of society. One can understand people who are on the breadline, people who are starving or cannot provide clothing for their children, misstating their tax returns and trying to evade paying tax, because the motivation-almost the necessity-for them to do so is very strong. But it is very difficult to understand people who have millions of dollars, all the money they are likely to need in their lifetime and more deliberately taking the view that it is perfectly all right, simply because of legal interpretations of very complex laws, to avoid their responsibility towards the society under whose protection they are brought up and from which, probably in this case more than other citizens of this society, they have benefited. This seems to me to be basically an immoral point of view, whichever way one looks at it, and one which, of course, is something of a national cancer not only here but in other countries. That kind of rip-off, of course, merely increases the pressure on the first type of person I mentioned, who is forced into a worse and worse situation because of the lack of conscience-I use that old-fashioned word-on the part of those people who could well have afforded to pay, but who were able to afford to devise the means not to pay.

It seems to me that, no matter how one hedges around the point, one comes back to that fundamental point. That, of course, is the reason why I will vote for this legislation. I am a senator for the State of New South Wales, which includes the city of Sydney, which has many poor people. It is a city in which from time to time old people who cannot survive on the pension and the rent allowance, because rents are so high in Sydney, live in appalling accommodation. There have been a number of fires in the Kings Cross area and some of these people have been burnt to death. I feel very deeply about this issue. I believe that those people in our society who think it is perfectly all right to use any sort of tax evasion scheme and avoid their fundamental obligations to society should consider that circumstance, and the degree to which they have contributed towards that sort of circumstance, and whether that enables them to live with their conscience. That seems to me to be the only final solution. It is a matter of morality. We know from the bitter experience of past years that it is not really possible to devise laws that can prevent this type of attitude from finding its mark.

I turn to the point that Senator Hill made, partly by way of interjection during Senator Elstob's speech, because I feel that he has a horse that does not run. He has said that the answer is to fix up the law. How can one possibly do that? The new scheme must be known about. It must emerge into the light of day. It must be identified and investigated. That having been done, legislation must be drafted to deal with it. That legislation has to be introduced into this place and passed by the Parliament. I would not have thought that any member of this Parliament could suggest to me that that is an instantaneous process. We all know from our experience that that would be an absurd point to make. I suggest, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if you concede that point you must concede that to sanctify the principle of non-retrospectivity in the tax laws is virtually to give people a licence to coin money. We are saying to them: 'We will not have any retrospectivity; therefore, we will allow you that period of eight months to a year or 14 months from now into the indefinite future in which you will be able to implement your schemes and get that money, and there is no way in which we can stop you'. I would be obliged if Liberal-National Party senators who may speak later would address this point because I think it is a basic point.

I am not saying that nothing could be done. I know that my colleague Senator Jack Evans is making valiant efforts and he is looking at a method whereby schemes have to be submitted to the Australian Taxation Office before they are entered into. But I suggest that even in that regard, unless there is some sort of feeling of morality in the community, that also could be got around in one way or another. The reason, of course, is that the taxation laws and, in particular, the Income Tax Assessment Act, are so enormously complex and the whole area is so difficult to administer and police that it is subject to evasion. This, of course, has been found in other countries. This Government is not the only government in the Western world to have faced this problem. There has been so-called quasi legislation in other areas to deal with it.

If the problem of detecting the schemes at the time they originate could be solved, the Senate might responsibly take a different view. But, until it is solved, surely we are talking in circles if we are saying that there is any way in which we can prevent the tax cheats from taking advantage of the situation. I do not have a desire to sanctify or embrace the principle of retrospectivity; far from it. I am the last person to believe that there should be penal legislation which is applied retrospectively, especially when some sort of penal sanction is involved. That has been mentioned in this debate from time to time. This is something that we must look at. As I said, whether one takes that principle of what one sees as retrospectivity or the tax equity principle as being the most important principle is a matter for individual people to look at. I respect honest and consistent convictions in this matter, as have been put forward by Senator Hill and some of my colleagues. They are not taking that stand because they are the friends of tax cheats; far from it. When representatives of the Government make stupid statements of that kind they are not advancing or helping this debate. It is a more serious debate than that; it is a more important debate than that. To reduce it to that level is to misrepresent it totally. I reject that kind of application.

I will look briefly at the question of retrospectivity because I think there is a point, which may or may not have validity, which I would like to bring to the attention of honourable senators and which I do not think has been raised previously. I believe that the Bills are not retrospective in the sense that they specifically change the law retrospectively. I think most of my colleagues on both sides of the chamber might agree with that point. I will look briefly at the implications of that point. The legislation which it is proposed should be amended did not in so many words describe bottom of the harbour type evasion or any other specific tax schemes and say that they were legal. Therefore, it would be absurd to say that the intent of the legislation and its creators would in any sense authorise or sanction such schemes. Surely it is our responsibility as legislators to look at that legislation and its intent. Whether its intent was imperfect is another matter. Do any of us who sit in this place believe that we are capable of creating perfect legislation? Of course we do not. We know that we try to approach that state as closely as we can. In some areas it is far more difficult to do so than in others. The area that we are talking about now is one of those areas.

I make the following point to those people who take such a view. Take a person who is driving at 45 kilometres an hour through an area which has a speed limit of 50 kilometres an hour. A year later the speed limit is changed to 40 kilometres an hour and the person is charged with having exceeded the speed limit a year earlier. That is absurd; it is not a reliable or accurate analogy with this legislation. I think those who make that kind of assertion and analogy are, again, obscuring the situation in a very difficult and complex area.

I think all parliaments and all members of parliament have attempted to create tax laws which make this sort of evasion impossible. I do not think there is any attempt to sanction it in any way, and we ought to regard that as a prime point. On the contrary, these schemes have tended to evolve from court interpretations. The real issue comes down to whether or not Parliament, in its wisdom, has the power or the right to legislate when it believes that a court decision has not led to a desirable state of affairs. There is also an inexorable logic in this argument.
