If one accepts, that because the court has said a certain thing, or because something has been devised which in some way has been construed from a court interpretation, this Parliament has no right subsequently to do anything about it-

TALK.START.PARA: —On a retrospective basis?

—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle misses my point. My point is that this legislation is not truly retrospective in that there is no legislation which directly sanctions these schemes. If one says that, one is entering, by inexorable logic, on to the shaky ground that this Parliament does not and should not have the power to look at past court decisions and alter them. The logical extension of that is to set the authority of the court system above and beyond that of Parliament.
—On a retrospective basis?

—It would be on whatever basis one cared to look at it-and I agree that here it would be on a retrospective basis. This is a nettle we have to grasp. It is not a simple or easy one but I concede the honourable senator's point and I ask her to concede mine-that that is the inexorable logic of the situation. If the honourable senator opposes this legislation she will be saying that that is the right of the High Court of Australia. I am not in any way impugning the High Court or anything in our court system; far from it. I am merely looking at the machinery of government. She will be saying that the High Court is the superior authority in the land and Parliament is not the superior authority in the land, that if the High Court makes a decision, whether subsequently legislators think it is right or wrong, whether it has led to the most monstrous consequences in the community, or whether it has led to appalling inequities-as this legislation has-it must be supported. I cannot for a moment understand how that sort of logic can apply, with all respect to those who agree with it, and that is why I am making this point. I think it is something of great and fundamental importance for us to consider because it goes far beyond this mere debate. It goes to the very nature of Parliament, the very right that Parliament has to operate in any future situation. Much as one may dislike the principle of retrospective legislation-much as I dislike it-one cannot apply this principle to the stage where one reduces, restricts or restrains the right of parliaments to do anything about it in the future. That seems to be something that we cannot accept. To accept that principle would be a very high cost for the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about the point made by Senator Hill-it was made by others also-which, with all respect, is utterly spurious. His point was that if we pass one piece of retrospective legislation it automatically means that all legislation will be retrospective and we have sanctified the general principle. That is utter rubbish. There is no way in the world that principles like that have to be applied universally or that there is any kind of precedent. Because this Parliament exercises its right to apply a quasi-retrospective law where it feels the need for it in one area, that in no way indicates that the Parliament has any obligation or requirement to do it on any future occasion any more than the numbers on one vote have to be the same in any future vote. That is simply saying that nothing new can ever happen, and that, of course, is a ridiculous point of view. It is one which ought to be put quietly away. Of course it is a fact that retrospective legislation has been passed by many parliaments before and indeed by this one. So that argument is quite ridiculous.

I ask: How often in political affairs can one afford the luxury of the unqualified support of a single principle, especially if it is in clear conflict with another principle? The whole of our business here, as so often happens when legislation becomes more complex, is of setting various interests against each other, of assessing what is good and what is right and of accepting the idea that any kind of new law tends to have a retrospective application. Of course it does. Take what happened when the first home owners scheme was changed. I know of young people who were working diligently to save and were ready to buy a house when the scheme was changed. Of course the requirements were altered and of course they had retrospective application.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not mean they had to give the money back, do you?
—They were not called on to give back the money but they did not get money which at that time they had every expectation they could have.
—But your application would be to take that money back from those people.

—No, not at all. With all respect, I suggest that there is a fault in logic there. Such people did not get money which they felt they had every reasonable expectation to get as a result of legislation. There is no real difference, in terms of money or anything else, between that situation and what these Bills propose to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to civil liberties as another example. Civil liberties is a principle we all respect. Yet we do accept limitations to our civil liberties in that we abide by laws which are decided on by parliaments to be to the common good. That does not alter our principle that we believe in civil liberties. We would agree that it is reasonable to limit our civil liberties to the extent that we do not drive our cars on the right hand side of the road, because that is obviously not to the good of the public. On the other hand, we may feel that it would be an unjustifiable infringement of our rights if we all had to have identity cards and once a week report our movements in writing to the police. That, of course, is the sort of rational interpretation of principles which any act of government, any process of government, has to encompass.

These things are a matter of judgment and a matter of degree. When one looks at history it is rather sickening to see how often most of the hardship, cruelty and suffering of this world have been due directly to making one principle or another a god applicable without reference to surrounding circumstances. It was on this basis that the Spanish Inquisition burned hundreds of people at the stake. Those people saw that as a perfectly respectable principle which they were not going to mitigate. Those who carried out those acts-I have done some reading of history of that period-did so in the absolute belief that such action was right and just and was even in the interests of the people who were burned. There are people of certain religious sects who even now would happily and with good conscience allow their children to bleed to death because of principles in which they firmly believe.

This is not an argument against principle or its value; it is an argument for the intelligent, perceptive application of principle, an attempt to convey to honourable senators the belief that one cannot take a principle and apply it universally except to one's own great harm. Also-this is the final and important point-if one applies that principle with universality, regardless of the surrounding circumstances, one will get an extremist situation in society. That is what happened at the time of the Spanish Inquisition when people were burnt to death. What is happening now is that people who quite deliberately and with intent have rejected their obligation to society to pay taxation will be able to get away with it. This is a matter of great concern to the Senate; but not only that, it is a concern to such a degree that we cannot allow the present intractable situation of conflict and division in the Senate to continue. Apart from anything else it does not reflect credit on this Parliament, and the community looks at it with cynicism and dismay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only virtue in having this piece of legislation dragged out for what I believe is the fifth time is to give new senators such as myself a chance to have a say on the Government's appalling tax record. I believe this current legislation is identical to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1983 (No. 2), which was introduced on 23 August 1983. Before I talk further on the record of that Bill, I would like to make a couple of points about the implications of this legislation. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in the other place earlier this week rightly called this legislation the Blue Hills of Canberra, and it is blue times for all of us under this Government today.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is dealing with more than just a legal document. Retrospectivity in legislation can only breed insecurity, and insecurity is relative to one's confidence in the law. If one loses confidence in the law and the legal process, one is heading for a complete breakdown in society. When one enters into a contract, one does so with confidence that the rules in the contract and the expected products of the arrangements are firm. When one starts to doubt those rules, one develops insecurity and instability, both socially and economically. One cannot have rules in a game that change when the game is over. If that happens people lose faith in the game itself. This insecurity bleeds over into other aspects of this legislation; namely, the involvement of personnel in companies who would be affected if this legislation were to be passed. This brings into doubt the whole question of the meaning of 'proprietary limited'. If this legislation were passed and approved the effects, social, economic and legal, would be enormous.

All these arguments have been spelt out time and again, but still the Government feels the needs to bring on this legislation. I really do not understand why this Government is wasting our time, and the taxpayers' money, in bringing this on knowing full well it will simply be rejected once again. I wonder how much money has been spent in staging what can only be called a farce. Is this Government so devoid of ideas that it must drag up old chestnuts like the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill time and again? To me, it is just another example of how this Government has become skilled at wasting money. It is another example of the Government's attitude to taxation reform.

The Opposition believes that there is a strong need for an overhaul of the taxation system in Australia today but it is being clouded by the debate about the so-called summit. The Opposition's policies on this matter are clear. They have been spelled out clearly to the electorate. Unlike the Government, the Opposition has concrete proposals for taxation reform. We believe there is an excessive and growing reliance on personal income tax. We believe that the tax base should be broadened and a greater reliance placed on indirect taxation. The Opposition has made firm commitments to the electorate on tax reform, as I have said. On the other hand, the Government has made no such commitment-not even before or during the election campaign. The Government still has no answers, and this is starting to show in the economy.

One has only to pick up newspapers to see how the economy is off the rails. The Government is trying all the time to talk up business activity, but with little effect. Today's Australian reports a top executive of a retail sales chain as saying:
. . . retail sales had been patchy in the past couple of months and there was an apparent weakness in consumer confidence.
Another gentleman from another company is reported as saying:
A division of one firm had 30 per cent of its orders on hold in March because customers could not meet credit requirements.
Another top executive is reported as saying:
. . . interest rates were high during the tax rundown period.
And they will get higher. Another gentleman, from the Australian Mutual Provident Society, did not see any significant evidence of major investment projects on the drawing boards.

One can go on and on quoting top business people in the community who are losing confidence in this Government. 'Big tax shortfall threatens Budget', according to yesterday's Australian Financial Review. 'Interest rates on move up', according to the Australian-and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) promised us they would fall. 'Australian dollar falling' says every newspaper. What answers has this Government to these problems? Ministers keep delving back into the past to try to find solutions, but problems will not be solved by looking to the past. They will be solved only at the time, now and in the future. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been on national television to assure us that the economy is in good shape and in safe hands. I wish he were right. The next day the dollar slumped again. The Government appears to have no answers to the tax problems facing Australia. Everything is being put into the tax summit basket. I am sure hundreds of thousands of Australians are beginning to think that this tax summit will be put into the too hard basket.

The Government, to avoid doing anything new, continuously reintroduces unacceptable legislation that has been rejected time and again. When will the Government stop its obsessive passion with retrospective legislation, with trying to ginger up the already declared dead issue of tax avoidance, and get on with the real work of tax reform? This Government appears to be incapable of coming to grips with the delicate subject of tax reform. If the various factions of the Australian Labor Party could agree among themselves how it should be done that would be a worthwhile excercise. The Treasurer is prepared to acknowledge a need for changes to indirect taxation, while the left factions are almost paranoid about the redistribution of wealth, about bringing retrospective legislation before Parliament. First, we have to create wealth. An editorial in the Australian last month said that few issues would be more important to the nation this year than tax reform. It continued:

The tax summit will have to grapple with reforming the Australian tax system in such a way to benefit the majority of Australians. Various trade unions, the ACTU and now the centre left faction of the ALP have all made contributions to the debate.

The worrying aspect of these contributions is their concentration on wealth redistribution and the apparent lack of concern for wealth creation. For it is very clear that the way you cut up the cake has a profound influence on the overall size of the cake.
Again, I am saying that we should look to the future, not to the past, in terms of legislation that affects the taxation system. Obviously taxation plays a major part in affecting personal incentive.

It is interesting to note how that incentive has been eroded over the years. In 1954-55, 30 years ago, income tax was 35 per cent of Commonwealth budget revenue; today it is 53 per cent. More striking, however, has been the increase in the marginal income tax rate for taxpayers on average weekly earnings, and how over the years the income tax burden has moved to the middle income earner. In 1954-55 the average marginal tax rate was 19 per cent. In the intervening years this has more than doubled to 46 per cent. Thirty years ago a man on average weekly earnings had to earn 18 times his weekly wage to move into the top income tax bracket; now he has to earn less than twice his weekly wage. So now in Australia we have a new definition of wealthy. Imagine what this has done to incentive-incentive for the individual and incentive for business. Without that incentive, both for the individual and the corporation, we have no growth, no turn-round in our economy, and no confidence in a government which tries to bring in retrospective laws on taxation. It is time that this Government stopped wasting our time on legislation it knows will not pass this chamber and started working on real tax reform. The Government knows the Opposition's policy on tax reform. We want reform. We believe an overhaul of the tax system is overdue. We believe there is too much emphasis on personal income tax. There has to be a shift in emphasis to encourage incentive, growth and expansion. When is this Labor Government going to start getting its act together? If its various factions cannot agree on a policy now, how is the summit some months away going to do it for them? The people elected this Government to govern, not to waste its time on summits or old, tired legislation. The cost of government is already outrageously high. At least let us try to give the electors some value for their money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As many of the speakers in this debate have said, we are debating for about the fifth time the matters to which the Bills that are before us-the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1985 and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1985-relate. It does make one ask why they are introduced again and again when the attitude of the Parliament with regard to retrospective legislation has been made perfectly clear. We have had from the Government a number of different Bills which have a retrospective effect. On some occasions the Senate has made it clear that it would accept those measures prospectively and in some cases it has taken action to ensure that Bills that would have that effect have been passed. These Bills are part of a series of Bills that have been introduced in different forms since the Government was first elected in 1983. The Government's approach to retrospectivity is not consistent in the matters that are covered by these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government keeps changing the Bills. It will be recalled that the first Bills of this type that were introduced were so draconian that we did not hear much about them at all after the Senate rejected them. I doubt whether the Government even understood the severity of the measures that were proposed. It went very quietly when the first group of Bills were rejected in this place. The Government has made a series of attempts to get this type of legislation passed. I note that the figures that are given with regard to these Bills total several hundreds of millions of dollars and the description of the Bills is that they will extend the scope of the legislation so that personal income tax avoided by former owners of companies stripped of pre-tax profits will be subject to recoupment.

I have to ask whether the Government is really serious about regaining tax revenue under the circumstances that it claims, because it has certain powers with regard to Bills of this kind and those that were rejected throughout last year. It could be said that it had the double dissolution machinery whereby it could have taken constitutional steps to have had Bills for retrospective tax passed following a double dissolution. The Government chose not to do that and to that extent one has to question the sincerity of the Government or the urgency in the mind of the Government with regard to its so-called recoupment tax Bills.

Senator Brownhill, who has just spoken, asked why the Government keeps bringing the Bills in; it knows the views of members and senators in the Parliament. The easy answer to that is that it is because of a commitment that it gave under the prices and incomes accord to the trade union movement, that it would introduce retrospective tax Bills. An attitude was expressed by the trade union movement that pay as you earn taxpayers did not have the options to manage their tax affairs and minimise their tax that others who were in business or who were in other associations had, so part of the commitment under the prices and incomes accord is that the Government will introduce retrospective legislation.

The Government talked about it at the last election when it did not have a tax policy and when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stumbled into a commitment to hold the summit that will be held in a month or two. As I said, at the time that it was talking about its prices and incomes accord and a tax summit it had the option of a double dissolution of the Parliament and of then putting its Bills to a joint sitting of the Parliament, thereby making a really strenuous effort to get them passed by the Parliament. I think the Government is quite relaxed when we reject the Bills for it, because it is then able to say that it has given some weight to the commitment it made to the trade union movement under the accord and it also gives it someone to blame for the size of the deficit and its own inability to control the growth of Government expenditure. That is not government; that is just passing the buck to a group of people here whom it chooses to call friends of tax cheats.

Each time it brings in these Bills it uses them as a vehicle to continue the myth that the former Government failed to stop the tax avoidance industry. As someone who acted for the former Treasurer (Mr Howard) in this place, I have to say that time and time again Bills were brought in to amend the tax law in order to stop contrived and artificial schemes that avoided tax, sometimes on a general basis, sometimes for specific schemes. It was well known that throughout the five-year period when John Howard was Treasurer more Bills were brought in to amend the tax law to stop artificial schemes than were brought in at any other time. For it to be said in Parliament that these Bills are the only way in which any attempt has been made to stop the artificial contrived tax schemes or tax avoidance schemes is quite misleading and quite dishonest.

Mr Dawkins, as Minister for Finance, made the public comment that the tax avoidance industry is dead. That is so, not because of any legislation of the present Government but because the series of changes made by the former Government to ensure that any of the contrived schemes that were able to be stopped by legislation or by the criminal penal legislation had the effect that was expected. These schemes have been stopped. The Hawke Government has attempted to bring in this type of legislation time and time again. It is sheer hypocrisy for it to present this legislation as an attempt to do something that had not been attempted to be done and something that needs to be done, thereby justifying penalising a selective group of people for schemes that go back over a decade.

Senator Mason presented a very circuitous argument about retrospectivity and his view that these were not retrospective tax Bills. It seemed to me to be a very confused argument, but he perhaps made it clearer when he talked about the changes that were recently announced by the Government to the homes savings grant scheme. This is a perfect example of the point that has been contended by the speakers for the Opposition with regard to retrospective legislation. In the past few days the Government has announced changes to the homes savings grant scheme-as a government is perfectly entitled to do-which will reduce the benefit that is to be paid in the future to people who are eligible to receive a benefit under that scheme. It is a scheme that has been extremely helpful to many thousands of people who have purchased homes under the scheme. The Government has announced that in future there will be a reduction or a change in the basis on which these grants will be made. The Government did not, in the last few days, bring in a Bill that retrospectively changed the homes savings grants scheme date from when it first instituted it in 1983. It did not bring in a Bill that required people who had a grant to repay that grant after they had purchased their home and after they had had the expectation of the use of the funds. That is the analogy that Senator Mason ought to see if he is talking about the retrospectivity of the Bills that are before us. It is changing the rules a long time after the transactions have occurred. In this case it is asking for a repayment of tax on a basis that did not exist at the time that these schemes were entered into.

We have heard some comment about the tax summit. Like, I am sure, most of my colleagues, I have received a number of submissions from organisations which intend to make representations to the tax summit. I have looked through the submissions that I have received and none of them mentions retrospectivity as a subject for urgent debate at the tax summit. A lot of the submissions talk about a tax system that ought to have equity, efficiency and simplicity. I think that we would all agree that those elements are desirable and necessary for compliance with any tax system. If one is looking for equitable tax system, I think one must look for fairness, justice and some certainty for the people who have to comply with it. I fail to see that there can be any fairness, equity or justice in a system that embarks in a general way on retrospective legislation. Such a system has been advocated by some speakers from the Government Party. Senator Elstob considers that retrospective tax legislation is quite desirable. Senator Mason on the one hand does not seem to believe that what is before us is retrospective and on the other hand believes that it is quite all right to bring forward legislation to change the law retrospectively after decisions that have been made in a court. Therefore, a person who has won a case in the court can be affected retrospectively by some change in tax law. I think the path advocated by Senator Mason would lead to a rather peculiar system of justice, given the court's role of interpreting legislation.

Many aspects of the Australian taxation system will undoubtedly be focused on in the tax summit. However, it perhaps would be desirable if the tax summit were preceded by a discussion on the level of government spending. One cannot look at taxation without looking at government expenditure. It is the essence of government to withdraw from the people the funds that are required to pursue government programs on behalf of the Australian people. An element of disquiet enters into that relationship when government expenditure reaches a punitive level and government gives people little choice in or does not allow them to meet their personal commitments and aspirations. The summit when considering tax as a matter of importance ought to be looking at the level of government spending and what people expect the Government to do on their behalf.

Points have been put forward with regard to what is at present the normal process of government expenditure, the review and effectiveness of programs and the reduction of expenditure wherever that is possible. I think public discussion so that people can have a complete understanding about this matter is a very healthy way to go about the pre-Budget stage. However, the situation is not helped when a government rejects immediately the undertaking of any sort of review in regard to changes that might be desirable. I know that it is very difficult for a government to look at the level of expenditure and go into the pre-Budget stage with so many commitments that seem to be inescapable and unavoidable-commitments to State governments, local government and organisations; commitments to cash payments under much of its social welfare legislation and things of that kind which lead to a high level of government expenditure in this country and which result only in what people might think of as a high level of taxation. So the prerequisite to looking at changes to the tax system when this matter is being discussed at the summit is a consideration of government programs and people's expectations of what government should do for them with their taxes.

Many proposals have been put forward suggesting that it will be easy to move to a system of broader indirect taxes and that somehow this will mean that there will be no more tax avoidance. That does not necessarily follow. Whatever system of tax, excise or collection by government is instituted, there will always be the requirement for compliance; there will always be the tendency for people to minimise the taxes or charges which they have to pay. That is why it is important that fairness and justice be readily seen. People who are being asked to comply with a system for the valid reason that a government is undertaking programs on their behalf should be able to understand the system. They should be confident that the system will not change after they have paid tax for a financial year.

The Australian Taxpayers Association is a broadly representative body of Australian taxpayers in the sense that it undertakes to put forward views of taxpayers throughout this country. That body says that tax avoidance 1970 style is virtually dead. It said that higher penalties and the specific changes to the law have achieved that. I have been making that point when I have talked of the changes that were made particularly during the five years when John Howard was the Treasurer of this country. We want to see such a situation. We would have expected the Government at that time to have reacted and brought in legislation that stopped tax avoidance schemes. Higher penalties and specific changes to the law have achieved that. The extra weapons that have been given to the Commissioner of Taxation to enable him to seek compliance with resources and to act in other ways have also been important elements in ensuring that tax avoidance 1970 style is dead.

The Australian Taxpayers Association went on to mention that the Commonwealth Auditor-General recently disclosed that about $1,000m of tax is being evaded because some people leave interest and dividends out of tax returns. That is another area in which compliance needs to be undertaken. People are aware that they should disclose their income from all sources. However, they evade tax by leaving details of money earned from interest and dividends out of their tax returns.

Another big area, of course, is the cash economy which has been partially dealt with by legislation and the prescribed payments scheme. I do not believe that anyone would assert that that legislation has been able to eliminate the cash economy and that tax is not being evaded because of non-disclosure. Therefore, we would see that further legislation is required in certain areas. We believe that further attempts should be made to gain compliance, to achieve the equity and fairness that I mentioned earlier and to get a simple and efficient taxation system. I do not believe that the only way to do this is to introduce retrospective legislation. Opposition speakers, not only in this debate but also in all the previous debates that have taken place on retrospective legislation, have stressed that fairness in the payment of tax, equity in the system and a fair sharing of the tax burden are all elements that they would wish to see in the taxation system. However, we cannot accept that retrospective legislation is the way in which this should be achieved.

As I said earlier, I cannot accept the deep sincerity that the Government has shown in this matter because it did not take the ultimate step to prove to everybody its belief in retrospective legislation. The Government could have had a double dissolution. It could have sought a joint sitting of the Parliament to make this the hallmark of its approach to tax legislation. But it did not do that. Again with barely a whimper, the Government has brought in retrospective legislation to this Parliament. It expects that the Senate will reject that legislation. I believe that that again will be the fate of these Bills when the vote is taken shortly.

Again, I put the proposition: If the Government is so serious about the legislation let it bring the Bills back again and let us reject them again. The Government will then have the double dissolution machinery on which it can be tested on a second occasion. Many speakers in this debate, including Senator Peter Rae who led for the Opposition, have indicated that the Opposition does not support the legislation. I feel very confident that our reasons for rejecting these Bills are understood by the Australian people. As I have said, the Government has certainly not made the point in its approach to the summit that it would accept or expect retrospective legislation to deal with matters of compliance or that the rules should be changed because of the detection of some scheme. I suggest that this debate shows again that prospective legislation to assist our taxation system is always considered sensibly and seriously by the Senate. However, I think the continued attempts to bring in retrospective legislation will result in the same sort of vote, certainly from members of the Opposition parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to record my strong opposition to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill for three basic reasons. Firstly, all legislation that imposes liabilities and penalties retrospectively is immoral, and ultimately threatens the entire basis of the rule of law. Secondly, these particular Bills are unjust and punitive in their operation, and threaten both the existence of many smaller businesses and the whole concept of limited liability, without which investment cannot operate. Thirdly, these Bills are a cheap political device on the part of this Labor Government, trying to unify its factions and conciliate the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the run-up to the great taxation summit.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Liberal senator from Western Australia, I am proud that my State Party has a consistent record of opposition to retrospective legislation. I am equally proud to stand here as a member of a Federal Liberal Party that will not countenance retrospective laws, penalties and liabilities in the future, in opposition and in government. It is the first principle of the rule of law, in our tradition of English common law, that if an activity is legal at a certain time, it cannot subsequently and retrospectively be made illegal, with penalties imposed upon those who were at the time acting within the law of the land.

It is not good enough to say that taxation is such a complex area that retrospective laws become necessary. It is also not good enough to argue that these Bills do not involve retrospective punishment, but merely the recoupment of tax revenue. The fact is that a retrospective liability is being imposed; tax evasion has always been illegal. It is not good enough to allege that all tax avoidance schemes were immoral and that this somehow justifies restrospectivity. So many activities in our society are legal but not necessarily moral. Honourable senators should consider the consequences of retrospective illegality and punishment, and the ramifications become even worse when we realise that some concepts of what is moral change over time. Are we to encounter retrospective penalties for the new deadly sins of sexism and racism? Supporters of the Government might argue that they have no further plans for retrospectivity, but the principle remains the same. The more we have retrospective laws in the taxation field, the greater the risk that this evil principle will spill over into other areas of law.

While I hold no brief for retrospective tax liabilities of any kind, I would reiterate the point made by other senators in this debate, and last year, that these Bills break new ground in imposing new liabilities going beyond the recoupment of normal taxation. These Bills are essentially punitive in their nature. They seek to recover this supposed avoided revenue at the highest possible rate, above the current maximum of 60c in the dollar.

Far worse, they proceed on suppositions that often bear no relation to the actual operations of private companies. The legislation assumes that retained earnings are distributed 100 per cent to shareholders, disregarding the fact that private companies can retain 70 per cent of earnings under laws existing for several years. In practice a private company can elect to pay tax on undistributed profits, which at 50 per cent would be less than the maximum rate of tax in the hands of the shareholders. This retrospective tax is being levied at a rate 41 per cent higher than would have occurred in a normal private company situation, where 70 per cent of the profits could be retained in the company. Either this legislation was drafted in blissful ignorance of private companies and small business, or it has been framed as a punitive measure.

By removing the so-called 'innocence clause' this Bill will actually create a situation where the vendor-shareholders who successfully avoided tax will be better off than those who went to promoters and unsuccessfully avoided tax. Shareholders in the former category are not liable for this recoupment tax. Such illogicality aside, it offends another established principle of natural justice that people can no longer claim as a defence the fact that they held an honest belief that the company did not have certain tax liabilities. All companies under the scope of these Bills are being treated, because of the abolition of the innocence clause, as though they were sent to the bottom of the harbour. This Bill will levy its retrospective penalties on shareholders of companies that did meet the requirements of existing tax and company law. For all the rhetoric about wealthy tax avoiders, this Government has not given much thought for the people who will be the actual victims of this legislation. Existing businesses will suffer the effective confiscation of working capital, or they will quite simply be sent to the wall. Business bankruptcies will not, of course, affect only the shareholders, but the employees who will lose their jobs.

While the major impact of this legislation will fall upon private companies, it can, of course, apply to public companies and thus threaten the entire concept of limited liability. Shareholders of public companies cannot be expected to have knowledge as to the legality or propriety of taxation and accounting procedures undertaken by the management. It was a particularly shameful aspect of the 1982 legislation that it lifted the corporate veil and recouped tax from ordinary shareholders of two public companies, Metro Industries Ltd and Westwools Ltd, who had, in effect, received nothing more than dividend payments. Our whole financial system is based on that principle of limited liability first expressed in Britain during the 1860s, that allowed the investment of limited capital without the risk of losing more than the amount ventured. Without it, only those wealthy speculators who seem to obsess the Australian Labor Party could afford to buy shares in any company, private or public.

This assault on the principle of limited liability will discourage people with modest incomes and savings from investing in any Australian enterprise. The Hawke Government showed what it thought of small investors when, in May 1983, it abolished the modest dividend rebate that reduced the double taxation of company profits. This punitive legislation now before the Senate would make people think twice before they invested in any company, particularly the elderly retired, who cannot cope with the thought of harassment by the Australian Taxation Office.

The point should be made that, with all these threats of new retrospective laws, this Government has created a climate of fear among many ordinary Australians. People not only fear the imposition of a capital gains tax, a wealth tax and other new taxes, but fear that they will somehow apply retrospectively. Perhaps they are right, given the intentions of the Hawke Government expressed in these two Bills before us. Whether or not such fears are correct, it is a sad state of affairs when people are concerned that they will be assessed on a block of land they have sold for a modest return after 25 years, or hesitate to transfer capital to close family members in case this Government dreams up a retrospective gift duty.

I return to my third point, that these Bills have far more to do with the confused and conflicting internal politics of the Labor movement than with furthering an honest taxation policy for Australia. On 3 March 1983 the outgoing Treasurer, Mr Howard, was informed by the Taxation Commissioner that the introduction of Part IVA of the taxation Act in May 1981 had 'from that date effectively put a stop to the promotion of new tax avoidance schemes of a blatant, artificial or contrived nature'. So much for all the rhetoric of the millions of dollars being ripped off by the tax avoidance industry. Even more interesting is a remark made in April last year, by the former Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, whose knowledge of tax avoidance I would not dream of challenging. He told a meeting of chartered accountants in Sydney that tax avoidance in Australia was 'dead as an issue'. Perhaps Mr Dawkins wanted to be polite to members of a profession subjected to generalised slanders throughout the tax avoidance debate, but I prefer to think that he was being honest. This honest appraisal of the situation last April was laid aside during the election campaign with more fanciful attacks on the tax avoidance industry. As a tactic it did not work very well in my own State of Western Australia where there was a 4 per cent swing against the ALP.

Having been of dubious value last December, the tax avoidance bogy is being revived here today as window dressing for the taxation summit. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) know that they have no hope of implementing any shifts from income to indirect taxation without the compliance of the Left, the Centre Left and the 'left right out' factions of the Australian Labor Party and of the other arm of this Government, the ACTU. Without any concern on the part of the Government as to the interests of the Australian economy or even of basic social justice, we are seeing the first crude political trade-off to obtain that support.

These Bills are supposedly directed at the people who do not vote ALP and who can be portrayed as evil tax avoiders to excite the passions of the mean-minded elements in the Labor movement. I might say as an aside that these sordid bargains will not stop with this legislation but will extend to the imposition of capital gains taxes and death duties, which the Treasurer knows to be economically disastrous, administratively costly and morally wrong, but which will be exacted by members of the Left and their allies. This charade would be comic if it were not for the fact that these two Bills will bankrupt small business, throw Australians out of work and punish many law abiding taxpayers for measures which were perfectly legal at the time. I hope that the Senate stands firm against the evil of retrospective legislation and consigns both Bills, partners in crime, to the scrap-heap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to look first of all at this legislation in its historical context and then at the legal and moral arguments. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill have quite a history. They relate initially to very serious government inaction on tax avoidance in the period from 1970 to 1980. That really was the basis on which it became possible for retrospective legislation to be accepted by this Parliament in the first instance. It was almost an admission of guilt by Parliament that for all those years governments and parliaments had allowed a situation to remain and, in fact, to be exacerbated to the detriment of the great majority of Australian taxpayers. I claim innocence in the lack of activity over that period. I was not then a member of the Parliament; neither was I a member of the Parliament when the first legislation was passed. I would have voted for that legislation because I believe in the principle contained in it, which I will describe in a few minutes. It became obvious that there was to be a search for scapegoats. This may have led, in the minds of some, to a vendetta against certain people in the community. Whether or not one agrees that a vendetta was justified, nevertheless, it was portrayed by the media as a vendetta because certain people were being hounded around the country as a result of certain unfortunate statements which were made in this Parliament under privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982 the Fraser Government passed the first legislation, but it would appear that it allowed certain loopholes for various pressure groups or friends-however one likes to describe them-in that legislation. The Fraser Government also left totally inadequate safeguards in that legislation for innocent people. That is an anomaly which the Australian Democrats have picked up subsequently. In fact, we currently have a Bill before the Senate to endeavour to remedy that anomaly. In 1983 we saw the first of the present Government's bottom of the harbour Bills. It became obvious that the Government intended to get rid of tax avoidance, if it was humanly possible, through the legislative process, not just by making it illegal to avoid paying tax but also by having the threat of retrospective legislation hanging over the head of any possible future tax avoider. The first of this Government's Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bills did not get through. We endeavoured to amend it but our amendment was lost on the second reading vote.

In 1983 the second of these Bills came to light. That Bill still contained no provision for people who we believed may have been able to prove themselves innocent but would have had to pay out in full despite their innocence. Also in 1983 the third T(UCT)A Bill was introduced by the Australian Democrats as a private senator's Bill to establish an anomalies tribunal. Then in 1983 the Government's third Bill was introduced. That Bill provided, in addition to the original provisions, some relief to public company shareholders. That piece of legislation was destroyed by Opposition amendments. Despite the fact that it was passed it was an abortive piece of legislation. Finally, in 1984, a piece of legislation similar to the second and fourth proposed Bills was introduced. That legislation also was not passed.

That led to a very interesting situation. The Government proclaimed that it would get tax cheats at any cost, that it would hound them until they paid their proportion of their ill-gotten gains to the Commissioner of Taxation. The Government was presented with a magnificent opportunity to carry out its threat because it decided to have an early election. It could just as easily have held a double dissolution at that time and given itself the numbers in the combined Houses to force through its legislation on bottom of the harbour tax avoiders, but it missed the opportunity. For reasons known only to itself it did not take advantage of the trigger that it had deliberately and carefully set up so that it could go to the people and say: 'We want your mandate for this legislation. We want to have the opportunity to get it through the Parliament despite the opposition of some people in the Senate. By going to you in a double dissolution you can give us enough numbers in the combined Houses of Parliament to get our legislation through'. But the Government ignored the opportunity, and so the legislation has still not passed through this Parliament.

Let me refer briefly to the Australian Democrats' record on this legislation because I think it is something that needs to be proclaimed. It is something for which not just Australian Democrats' senators but also Australian Democrats' members, supporters and voters can feel justifiably very proud. We have been absolutely consistent in our approach to this legislation, which is more than can be said for any other political party. We have been totally consistent. We have had divisions in the Australian Democrats, as there have been divisions in the votes of members of the Liberal Party of Australia. Our divisions truly represent the divergent views of the total community on this legislation-a community which is torn between two principles. There is the principle which holds that retrospective legislation is not acceptable. I think that that feeling is based in part on the fear of the extension of the retrospective legislation principle. Whether that is justified or not, that is, nevertheless, the way many people in Australia perceive this legislation. On the other hand, some of us believe that the receivers of illegally obtained wealth-I stress 'illegally obtained wealth'-should not be allowed to rob their fellow Australians.
I ask: Who are the friends of the tax cheats? That is a phrase that has been used not only in elections but also in this place from time to time. Just who are the friends of the tax cheats?

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody over there except you and Mason; that is who.

—Let us have a look at who are the friends of the tax cheats so that Senator Walsh can load his firearms with buckshot instead of with a single shot. There are many friends of tax cheats. There are those who oppose retrospective legislation and who I accept may be caught up in that accusation, but they are at least doing so as a matter of principle. There are those who legislate to ensure that loopholes exist in tax laws for the benefit of their friends and supporters. They are a lot more subtle, a lot more clever and a lot less obvious.

SPEECH.PARA: There are those who ignore the legislative flaws for years and years thereby allowing the tax avoidance industry to flourish. That sweeps up many people, including most of the people in this Parliament today, including even Senator Walsh and including Ministers and shadow Ministers who, over many years, allowed the tax avoidance industry not just to exist but to grow in such a way that those of us with any sort of a conscience felt guilty for our Australian Parliament because it was allowing this to happen. It was allowing an industry to be prostituted, promulgated and promoted blatantly by professional people across this land. In my opinion other friends of tax cheats include those in High Courts who distorted the interpretation of laws to benefit fellow conservatives. I use that word not in a political sense but in a sense that they were fellows who were doing very nicely, thank you, out of the present system. They did not want to change anything because it was to their benefit to allow the tax avoidance industry to flourish. We had a quite ridiculous interpretation of section 260 of the tax Act which subsequently practically every lawyer, every constitutional lawyer and every parliamentarian has proclaimed to be a ridiculous interpretation. But we lived with that for many years as a result of an interpretation in the High Court.

Finally, the friends of the tax cheats include those who aid and abet the massive distortion of our tax system. That includes some professional people. I will not sweep everybody into this category. But these people know who were the lawyers and the accountants in their professions who were deliberately setting up this industry. They are the friends of the tax cheats and they are the ones who still have not been placed on the hook of any piece of legislation. They are still enjoying their professional reputations as lawyers and accountants without what I believe should be the stigma associated with their acts over the last decade.

Speaking for myself, I have voted in favour of every piece of tax avoidance legislation that has come to this Parliament. I have spoken vigorously inside and outside the Parliament about the tax avoidance industry and about tax avoiders. In my first few months within this Parliament I probably became the most lobbied person in this Parliament, as a result of listening to the pleas of those who had been caught up by the Fraser legislation and who were about to be caught up by the Hawke legislation on tax avoidance. Whilst listening to them sympathetically and considerately, I was persuaded by their arguments-I heard all of them-that there needed to be some easing up on the tax avoidance industry. I also took deliberate steps to clarify the hazy lines between the tax avoidance practices of some people and the legal, justifiable and moral tax minimisation practices in which I suspect practically all of us engage. I went so far as to introduce a tax avoidance schemes Bill which did provide machinery for having tax avoidance schemes registered, approved by the Treasurer in prospect, so that we would not ever again have to go through the processes of retrospective legislation to catch those who had avoided their obligations to pay their taxes.

All governments have been guilty of inaction and I have mentioned this. But what needs to be stressed is that while that inaction of governments was tolerated, 15 million Australians were victims of it. Every million dollars which one of these frauds managed to get away with meant that more tax had to be drawn into the revenue system of government through increased taxes for the rest of the taxpayers of Australia. I think that there is justification for this legislation. I think we need to look at it coolly and calmly in this context. It is a false argument to propose that people who would be caught by this legislation behaved legally at the time. I want to stress this: This legislation is being introduced because of the illegal acts of people at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —What law did they breach?

—If Senator Rae is not aware of the law which precludes the destruction of company records, I am surprised and disappointed. The honourable senator should hear me out. He does not deny that that law was breached. The acts of tax evasion were illegal because that law was breached. The laws of this land were broken. Nobody has denied that. The laws of Australia, in terms of tax payments, were broken because company records were destroyed. This legislation deals with the beneficiaries of those illegally gotten gains. I go further: It does not, as so many people have implied, impose penalties on those beneficiaries. It does not create criminals through the retrospective laws. There goes the argument of most of the people who claim that this retrospective legislation is horrendous and is a precedent for all sorts of other laws being changed. This piece of legislation does not make criminals of the people who are caught up by it. That is a red herring. It is a straw man argument. No criminals are being created by this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: All that this legislation does is to collect taxes from people on the moneys which were legally taxable but which were avoided by illegal acts. That is all this legislation is doing: It is collecting the taxes which were evaded-I go further; not avoided, but evaded-through an illegal act. But because those moneys happened to finish up in somebody else's hands-that was the clever part of the deal; that was the way around the technicality of the law-Senator Rae is saying that that is okay and that makes it legal. He says that the illegal act becomes legal because the money finished up in somebody else's hands. What an argument! What an absolutely fallacious argument to suggest that it is okay to receive ill gotten gains but that it is not okay to take an illegal action to create those ill gotten gains.

Senator Rae will have us believe next that it is okay to accept stolen goods-another form of ill gotten gains. If there is not an element of stealth in this action there is stealth from 15 million Australians. It is not just stealth from Senator Rae or another individual: It is stealth from 15 million Australians. Because it is stealth from all of us, Senator Rae is saying: 'Let them get away with it; there is no real crime there'. He is saying that we should let them get away with all these millions-or billions, as we are starting to discover-of dollars because they got the money in sweet innocence, they were the third party, they were only the receivers of illegally gotten gains. That is the argument for anti retrospectivity.

I make another plea to this Government and to this Parliament to consider the people who have been caught up in all innocence-there are a few-with the Fraser legislation and who would be caught up with this legislation if it were passed. I have asked for a separate, special appeal system to be provided for those people. I still ask for that. I put it to the Government that if it supports the Bill that I put before this Parliament it will destroy one of the few remaining arguments that the Opposition may have in the market place-the argument that this legislation or any bottom of the harbour legislation may pick up a genuinely innocent person. If we take that argument away from members of the Opposition, there is a chance that next time around a few consciences will start to be pricked and this legislation will be passed. In any case, whether or not the Government wants to do it for that reason, there is a justifiable reason for putting down and passing a piece of legislation which gives a justifiable right to innocent sufferers from the original T(UCT)A legislation to appeal, to have their assessments reduced or withdrawn or to be given additional time to pay. That is what the Bill that I have introduced would do.

This has been an emotional debate because some very high principles are at stake. I hasten to add that I respect the views of both sides in this debate, whether or not they agree with my arguments. I respect those who believe in the principle of retrospectivity and fear where it may lead us. Similarly, I believe that this Parliament has a responsibility to the people it represents to kill the tax avoidance industry and to ensure that, not only in retrospect but also in prospect, all Australians pay their share of tax whether they be pay as you earn taxpayers, small business people-those two categories have paid much more than their share over recent years-or millionaires who can manipulate the system so that they pay no taxes at all but get not only all the benefits of their ill-gotten gains but also all the benefits that this country provides for them.

I ask all honourable senators to give very careful consideration to this vote and to do as they have done previously. I appeal particularly to honourable senators on this side of the House to be prepared to divide, which they did previously on a T(UCT)A Bill. I ask them to be prepared to stand up for what they really believe in. If we look back through the Hansard records of those original speeches we find that some very high-principled, moralistic speeches were made which could equally be made on this legislation. They were made then by members of the Liberal Party. I believe that those members who felt that way then may still feel that way today and I hope that they will be given the opportunity to express that feeling in a vote on these Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation.
—You may proceed.

—Senator Jack Evans suggested that I approved of illegal acts and that I had suggested that no action should be taken against the people who had perpetrated illegal acts. That was a figment of his imagination, a total invention. I have never said any such thing, nor do I believe it. I simply make it quite clear that I do not approve of illegal acts and I do not approve of the idea that no action should be taken against the people who are guilty of illegal acts. I do not take it any further than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not heard the entire debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1985 and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1985, but I assume that most of the speakers delivered the set piece speeches which they have delivered in the past. One or two new senators also spoke. I think Senator Jack Evans gave a very good summing up of the case. It is a pity that the best of the Australian Democrats senators will not be here after the end of June. Two reasons have been advanced by the people who will vote again to protect the ill-gotten gains of tax evaders. The first is a claimed objection in principle to retrospective legislation. That argument could perhaps be legitimately used by Senator Chipp or Senator Haines, who have always voted against retrospective tax legislation. It could legitimately be used even by a number of people in the Liberal Party; I do not have all their names.
—I am one of them.

—Senator Rae tells me that he is one of them and I concede that. However, it is not an argument which can legitimately be used by Senator Harradine or by 14 of the present Liberal-National Party senators who voted for retrospective legislation in 1982 and have voted against retrospective legislation ever since. In defence of the Liberal-National Party senators who have that contradictory voting record, one could enter a plea of mitigation; that is, that they were under party pressure, party discipline, to vote the way they did in 1982. For Senator Harradine, of course, no defence whatsoever is admissible. Senator Chipp has long been on the public record claiming that he was offered half a million dollars to vote against legislation of this type. It has always been my view that Senator Chipp had an obligation to state to the Senate who it was that made that offer, but I accept his statement that such an offer was made. I believe, as I have said before, that short of a death threat an attempt to bribe a member of Parliament is the greatest possible contempt of Parliament. I wish that the people who purport to have some respect or some affection for the claimed dignity of the Parliament and the Senate would stand up and take some action when the integrity of the Parliament is threatened in the most fundamental way.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reason advanced for voting against the Government's legislation-for which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave a specific commitment in his policy speech during the election campaign last year and for which the Government therefore has a mandate-is that there is no longer any need for retrospective legislation of this type because, it is asserted, the Part IVA amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act of May 1981 have closed off for all time the possibility of similar fraudulent tax avoidance. That claim is wrong. It has been refuted by the success of trust stripping for charity donations-what has become known as the new generation trust strips. Under that scheme donations to charity, which are payable 80 years hence and which therefore have a negligible present value, have been fully deducted from current taxable income. It has been upheld in the courts. The perpetrators of that scheme, thanks again to the actions of the same honourable senators who will defeat these Bills, have been allowed to walk away with $9.5m, essentially on the same spurious grounds-that they were opposed in principle to retrospective legislation.

I know Senator Rae will not like what I am about to say because I think it succinctly sums up the attitude of honourable senators who will vote against this Bill. What they are saying to would-be tax avoiders or tax evaders-whatever you like to call them-is this: 'If you have been robbing the till all week and we find out on Friday that you have been doing this we will say that if you continue to rob the till you will have to pay back any further money that you steal but that what you have stolen to date you can keep'. Essentially that is the attitude of the people who will defeat this legislation. They are telling thieves that they will be under no obligation to repay what they had stolen before the theft was detected; they will be obliged to repay only what was stolen after the theft was detected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you concede that these thieves involved in the bottom of the harbour scheme were doing it legally? There is a great deal of difference.

—If Senator Chipp wants to introduce one of those fine casuistic lawyer's distinctions, that is so. I expect he introduces it as a point of law. As Malcolm Fraser used to say, there ought to be an obligation on citizens over and beyond the strictest requirement of the law. However, I am indebted to Senator Chipp for raising that point because it opens up the whole question of the ethics of the legal profession, a question to which I think the legal profession ought to address itself. For instance, we had the spectacle in Dublin last year of one of the most prestigious QCs in the United Kingdom arguing before a court for weeks that it could not extradite a man because he was not Robert Trimbole. The same QC appeared in court the next week and said: 'All right, that was a fib, he is Trimbole. But you still cannot extradite him'. He then gave some other reason. No odium whatsoever accrued to that prestigious QC for so arguing a case. The morals of the legal profession are so flexible that they will accommodate anything. There seems to be no limit on the degree or amount of anti-social action which the legal profession will accommodate.
—I agree with you 100 per cent and I commend you for saying what you have just said.
—I suggest that as Senator Chipp is still a qualified lawyer he ought to take the matter up with the legal profession. The ethics of the legal profession are appalling.

SPEECH.PARA: I really do not think there is any point in going into this matter in any more detail, except to state once again the simple proposition-proven by the success of the new generation trust strips-that Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act does not provide an iron clad guarantee. I make the concession to the legal casuists that such actions may not be technically fraudulent but they are certainly in every other sense fraudulent. Actions aimed at defrauding the public revenue are not precluded by Part IVA. The only way to ensure that potential perpetrators of fraud of the public revenue will not be allowed to keep the gains from their fraud is for this Parliament-which in the present context means this chamber-to serve notice on the community to issue a credible threat of retrospective legislation and retrospective recovery. If such a threat were issued the tax avoidance industry would be killed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Capital punishment never cut out murder.

—That was a rather silly interjection. Unlike claims made to the contrary during the debate, this legislation does not impose any criminal penalties. It seeks to recover money which ought to have been paid to the Commissioner of Taxation years ago. It imposes no criminal penalty. Until this Parliament issues a credible threat of retrospective legislation perpetrators of tax avoidance-evasion schemes will be able to continue to practise their anti-social craft with at least some prospect of success.

—I claim that something Senator Walsh said-
